greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest divisor of n coprime to 30. I.e., a(n) = max { k | gcd(n, k) = k and gcd(k, 30) = 1 }.
comment: This is the sequence of the largest divisor of n which is coprime to 30. The product of the first 3 prime numbers is 2*3*5=30. This sequence gives the largest factor of n which does not include 2, 3 or 5 in its prime factorization.
link: Barry Wells, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1024
example: The largest factor of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 not including the primes 2, 3 and 5 is 1. 7 is prime and therefore its sequence value is 7. For p > 5, p prime, gives a(p) = p. As 14 = 2*7, a(14)= 7. As 98 = 2*7*7, a(98)= 49.
xref: A051037 gives the smooth five numbers, numbers whose prime divisor only include 2, 3 and 5. A132740 gives the largest divisor of n coprime to 10. A065330 gives a(n) = max { k | gcd(n, k) = k and gcd(k, 6) = 1 }.
Largest divisor of n coprime to a prime factor of 30: A000265 (2), A038502 (3), A132739 (5).
results.author: Barry Wells (wells.barry(AT)gmail.com), Sep 25 2009
